title.narrative: Mid-Term Review for the Promoting Renewable Energy in Mae Hong Son Province Project
FS Promoting Renewable Energy in MHS Province
FS Promoting Renewable Energy in MHS Province

description.narrative: Promoting Renewable Energy in Mae Hong Son Province
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Energy - power generation

Increase of power generation capacity and usage from RE systems in MHS;
Percentage of power generation capacity nationally from RE systems.

comment.narrative:
RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 17.0 MW (on-grid) and 2.4 MW (off-grid);
1.45% grid power generation and 5.37% grid+off-grid power generation is by RE.

description.narrative: Project Objective: To overcome barriers to the provision of Renewable Energy (RE) services in integrated provincial renewable energy programmes in Thailand
Increase of power generation capacity and usage from RE systems in MHS

comment.narrative: RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 17 MW (on grid) and 2.4 MW (off-grid)
By the end of the project RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 27.06 MW (on grid) and more than 2.4 MW (off-grid). This is equivalent to an increase of at least 55,000 MWh/year)
RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 29,220 MW (on grid) and 255 kW (off-grid). (June 2015)

description.narrative: Percentage of power generation capacity nationally from RE systems

comment.narrative: 1.45% grid power generation and 5.37% grid + off-grid power generation is by RE
By the end of the project the proportion of power generation from installed or planned RE systems nationally is 6% (grid) and 8% (grid + off-grid)

description.narrative: Models for RE generation & application which can be replicated in other areas demonstrated

comment.narrative: No new models for RE generation & application.
At least 3 new models for RE generation & application developed and operational. Models ready to be replicated in other areas (hydro, solar and biodigesters)

Several models related to RE generation & application, service delivery, fund management and sustainable utilization of RE were sketched out but not finalized. For instance policy support for RE applications & energy access in forest reserved area; facilitation to local government in RE technologies, operation & maintenance (O&M); community management for productive uses of RE technologies; women empowerment in ICS realization and promotion; RE revolving fund (Clean Energy Fund) for income generation and livelihoods improvement for the marginalized groups.

description.narrative: Outcome 1: Strengthened institutional, organizational and social capacity results in planning, management and implementation of integrated RE programmes in MHS, Chiang Rai, Chiang Mai and Tak
No. of working RE management models established

comment.narrative: None
At least 3 management models established (off-grid hydro, biodigesters, solar)

A management structure for off grid microhydro power was established. The agreed structure includes responsibilities of provincial and local concerned agencies and was agreed with the participation of local communities.

description.narrative: No. of RE projects proposed by government agencies in line with provincial plan

comment.narrative: None
At least 2 RE projects proposed by government agencies in line with provincial plan

3 RE (micro-hydro power) projects were proposed and developed by 3 local governments (Tambon Administrative Organizations or TAOs), in line with local and provincial plans. TAOs will be the owner of the plants. (Completed)

description.narrative: Outcome 2: Financially sustainable RE systems operational in MHS, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai and Tak
Increase in invested amount for RE in MHS (all sectors)

comment.narrative: Investment in 2007 = 486 million baht (figure for MHS province)
By the end of the project at least an additional 800 million baht[2] is invested in RE systems in MHS compared to the baseline

description.narrative: Amounts available in the form of micro-credit for communities wishing to establish RE systems

comment.narrative: No micro-credit available
By the end of 2015 at least 10 million baht is available in the form of micro-credit to individual villages for installation of RE systems

description.narrative: Village revenues from grid-connected RE systems

comment.narrative: No income
By the end of the project village-level revenues from sale of electricity in grid-connected systems amounts to at least 15 million baht per year[3]

1 additional on-grid solar farm project approved, installed and operational in MHS by end of 2016 (capacity 500 kW).
100 SHS rehabilitated in MHS by end of 2016 (100*120 Wp)
200 solar lanterns sold in MHS by end of 2016 (200*2.5W)

2 potential locations for on-grid solar farms were selected and under land legal review.

2 solar lanterns demo models were selected and tried-out to find the most suitable one for MHS off-grid poverty stricken areas, in term of technology application and affordability.
3 potential locations for biodigesters at schools and another 9 at farms were identified and assessed.
3 off-grid micro-hydro power projects were approved by MHS province. 2 out of 3 projects are under investigation of land use permit by MNRE.
0

14 villages of 3 ethnic groups (Tai Yai, Karen, Lanna), located in peri-urban and rural areas, in which 55 ICS have been tried out and are being used.
(Completed)

description.narrative: Outcome 3: Technical support is available locally for the development, management and maintenance of RE applications in MHS, Chiang Rai, Chiang Mai and Tak

comment.narrative: No knowledge or expertise centre easily available;
4 village technicians trained to operate and maintain off-grid hydropower plant by end of 2016

comment.narrative: No knowledge (centre) or experts easily available
10 village technicians trained to maintain rehabilitated SHS by end of 2016

description.narrative: An improved design of an ICS suitable for situation in MHS

comment.narrative: No knowledge (centre) or experts easily available
Improved design for ICS suitable for MHS finalized
Improved design for ICS suitable for MHS finalized and being used among 55 project volunteers. (Completed)

description.narrative: Outcome 4: Policies facilitate up-scaling and replication of RE systems in Thailand

Documented and published experiences/lessons learned from all technologies implemented by end of 2016
Centre of learning approved and operational in MHS by end of 2016
Guidelines published
No. of lessons learned included in policy making at central level

comment.narrative:
None
None
None
None

By end of 2016 all lessons learned documented and published
Centre of learning approved and operational by end of 2016
At least 2 guidelines for replication published e.g. a) on management models for off-grid applications b) incentive schemes/financial model for RE
At least 2 important lessons learned included in policy making at central level

0
0
One guideline for local technicians on technical field assessments to determine potential for off-grid micro-hydro power was published and 700 copies disseminated to provincial and local concerned agencies and TAOs in MHS.
Information on several topics and themes of important lessons learned i.e. on micro-hydro power policy, financial support mechanisms, appropriate service delivery models for accessible and affordable RE technologies in poverty stricken areas for off-grid marginalized groups have been gathered. This information will be used in coming year to determine key learnings for inclusion in policies at central level.

title.narrative: Mangroves for the Future (MFF)/ Small Grants Facility

description.narrative: Mangroves for the Future (MFF)/ Small Grants Facility (SGF)
Mangroves for the Future/ Small Grants Facility, Phase 3
Energy - policy, planning and administration
- Replication of good practices - Improved fertility of coastal resources shown by catching statistics - Co-management system set up

comment.narrative: - Individual practices; by 1.5 years, good practices of community-based resources management have been part of local school curriculum - Depletion of marine and coastal resources; by 1.5 years, 30% increase of CBOs working on sustainable resources management - No coordination with local government; by 1.5 years, CBOs at the target areas have formed its network in natural resources management

title.narrative: FS Catalyzing Sustainability of THs PA System

description.narrative: PIMS: 3825 GEFSEC ID: 3517 Catalyzing Sustainability of Thailand's Protected Area System

title.narrative: Evaluation of UNDP/GEF Project on Catalyzing Sustainability of Thailand's Protected Area System

description.narrative: PIMS: 3825 GEFSEC ID: 3517 Catalyzing Sustainability of Thailand's Protected Area System.
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Project implementation at Tarutao National Park

description.narrative: capital of a political entity
first-order administrative division
second-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration

1)Policy guidelines and rules enable successful implementation of effective management plans, designing new revenue mechanisms, and improving co-management efforts, particularly with communities and local government. 2. Formal DNP management and financial effectiveness capacity programs in place. 3. Completed objective-driven PA management plans and budgets provide clarity on financial need / gap. 4. Improvements in DNP budget allocations, and increased non-government PA revenues and sources reduces financial gaps. 5. Co-management approaches mainstreamed and effective.

comment.narrative:
Regulations and policies exist but are not clear enough, or enforced properly. Gaps in specific regulations may be hindering PA achievement.
Limited formal capacity programs or materials.
Less than 50% of PAs have management plans. Currently PA or system financial gap is not clear as not all PAs have management plans and DNP budgeting system is based on rough estimates and historical norms.
Approximately 75% of non-salary PA system financing is government budget and 25% is tourism. No other significant sources exist.
Co-management approaches between PA (such as Complex) and with communities and other stakeholders (PAC) are relatively new, poorly understood, and underutilized.

description.narrative: To overcome barriers to effective management and sustained financing of Thailands protected area system.

1. Policy guidelines and rules enable successful implementation of effective management plans, designing new revenue mechanisms, and improving co-management efforts, particularly with communities and local government.

comment.narrative: Regulations and policies exist but are not clear enough, or enforced properly. Gaps in specific regulations may be hindering PA achievement.
New policy guidelines, and / or new policies, in place to facilitate PA management planning, budgets, finance and co-management.

1) Recommendations on the PA system plan and the policy brief on innovation to make Thailand's protected areas more valuable have been finalized. A high-level consultation platform will be organized by Q3/2015.
2) The 5-year integration plan has been completed; the national park management master plan has been revised by updating some information related to marine national parks (emerging MPA reform issue)
3) The report on preparation of a National Protected Area System Plan sourcebook is being translated prior to use in various settings for discussion on the following issues: proposed PA categories and zones within PAs; PA governance; relations with local and resident communities, (including integration with surrounding land use; the various policies that may need modification to fit within DNP practices; the numerous potential funding mechanisms with a view to selecting those that are most likely succeed; how to generate the many benefits to protected areas; and how to build broader support from multiple stakeholders; and how to build the institutional and staff capacities to implement the improved management of Thailand's PAs.

description.narrative: 2. Formal DNP management and financial effectiveness capacity programs in place.

comment.narrative: Limited formal capacity programs or materials.
Specific programs and materials in place.

The trainings and capacity building workshops organised under the project remains piecemeal and has not been systematically integrated into the DNP system yet. The trainings/ capacity buildings have been designed around the key themes of CATSPA, including sustainable financing, financial scorecards, Management Effectiveness for PA: tools and approaches, the economics of biodiversity and ecosystem conservation, communication for conservation, as well as SMART patrolling. The two core curricular drafted last year have not yet been rolling out, due to the lack of engagement with the core groups of the Effectiveness Unit and the Training Division of DNP. The rapid assessment on training need assessment has been done, and it will inform the development of Marine Protected Areas Capacity Building module, to support DNPs in the reform of the marine protected area management. The consultations with the Training Division, The Recreation Division, as well as the superintendents of the marine protected areas have been undertaken twice, and the outline of the module has been developed.

description.narrative: 3. Completed objective-driven PA management plans and budgets provide clarity on financial need / gap.

comment.narrative: Less than 50% of PAs have management plans. Currently PA or system financial gap is not clear as not all PAs have management plans and DNP budgeting system is based on rough estimates and historical norms.
100% of project demonstration PAs and a growing number of PAs system wide have management plans and budgets (target is 65% by end of project).

80% of project demonstration sites have management plans.
Management Plans are under development for Mae Wong NP and Klong Lan NP. The latter will be integrated into the Thung Yai-Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary World Heritage Site for UNESCO submission.
As noted previously, management plans are in place for Doi Inthanon NP, Eastern Forest Complex, Tarutao (embedded in the Andaman Sea Management Plan) and Huay Kha Kheng WS.

description.narrative: 4. Improvements in DNP budget allocations, and increased non-government PA revenues and sources reduce financial gaps.

comment.narrative: Approximately 75% of non-salary PA system financing is government budget and 25% is tourism. No other significant sources exist.
Additional revenue sources contribute an additional 10% to 5 project PA demonstration sites and PA system plans in place to target a 10% increase across system.

There is no increase in the PA revenues yet. However, the Doi Inthanon Conservation Trust Fund has been launched with strong partnership with the private sector and looks set to that the park will gain additional source of funding supporting their management. Further revenue schemes have been studied with recommendations provided by a consultant for the potential for launching a scheme for a special car license plate with the Depart of Land Transport to support Thai PAs, and for proposals to enhance funding for MPAs, through the introduction of the conservation car plates.

description.narrative: 5. Co-management approaches mainstreamed and effective.

comment.narrative:
Co-management approaches between PA (such as Complex) and with communities and other stakeholders (PAC) are relatively new, poorly understood, and underutilized.
UNDP Financial Scorecard Total Score = 34%

Complex management plan and budget analysis reveals value of Complex approach. PACs are fully functioning and contributing to management in 5 project demonstration PAs.
UNDP Financial Scorecard Total Score = 55%

A final draft of Eastern forest Complex management plan was developed and is being adapted through a newly established EFCom Protected Areas Advisory Committee (PAC)'s.The positive experience with the creation of the Doi Inthanon National Park Business Plan is also being studied for application at EFCOM and Tarutao.
PACs in the demonstration sites are all functional and contributing to management.
The 2014 UNDP Financial Scorecard score is 31.36%. (The baseline UNDP financial scorecard score was 33.90%)

description.narrative: Improved governance supports enabling environment for long term PA system sustainability.
1.1 5-year integrated national PA system management plan and financial strategy endorsed.

comment.narrative: Currently PA or system financial gap is not clear as not all PAs have management plans and DNP budgeting system is based on rough estimates and historical norms. Formal, bottom-up, financing strategies do not exist.

A financial gap analysis reveals true financial needs, or gaps, for the 5 project pilot PAs and the PA system. The System and 5 PAs have financing strategies. Approach is being rolled out to full PA system.

The final 5-years National Parks Management Plan was refined and updated, in particular relating to marine national parks.
The financial gap and needs assessment has not yet been completed for the PA system. Nevertheless, the business plan for Doi Inthanon NP has been under development but faces difficulty on getting actual expenditure of each government agency in relate to key conservation activities they provided for the park annually.

description.narrative: 1.2 Policies strengthening role of PA Advisory Committees and community participation in PA management is in place.

comment.narrative: Limited guidance or training material exists to promote collaboration with Local government or PA committees.
Policy is strengthened and guidance materials exist.

No result on policies being strengthened nor guidance materials in place yet. The project has reached the level that it managed to form the Eastern Forest Complex (8 PAs) Protected Areas Advisory Committee (PAC) with 34 members consisting of the Foundation to Protect the Forests in the 5 Eastern Province, under the royal patronage, the deputy-chairman of Chantaburi Province;s Chamber of Commerce, the Mayor of Rayong, the Chief Executive of the Chantaburi Provincial Administrative Organization, the East Water Company, the Mab Ta put Industrial estate, Regional Water Authority, head of sub-districts etc. The facilitation, the coordination, and the mechanism to run the EFCOM PAC forms the foundation of the policy recommendations and guidance materials towards the development of complex-level PAC. .

description.narrative: 1.3 Effective M&E and knowledge-based data management system is in place to assess progress and to inform policy decisions

comment.narrative: Actual management and cost performance is not tracked. No formal M&E system looking at total effectiveness of performance exists. Adaptive management is not utilized.
DNP has M&E program (utilizing METT and UNDP Scorecard or similar) and is evaluating PAs, starting with 5 project PAs. Adaptive management measures and processes are in place.

The 2014 METT assessment in the 5 demonstration sites has been taken in September 2014.
Later on, the METT is replicated for Krang Kra Chan Complex (the proposing World Heritage Site) to assess management effectiveness.

description.narrative: Institutional and individual capacities enhanced.
2.1 Effectiveness Unit in place to support project and institutionalized for long-term role in DNP.

comment.narrative: No such integration body within DNP supporting complex management approach

An Effectiveness Unit is in place to support project and is considered for long term role within DNP e.g. being able to generate non-budgetary revenue, complex management approach and PA co-management effectively demonstrated.

The Effective Unit or Institution of Innovation Protected Areas and National Parks is in place. And the new Marine National Parks Section establishment will be a potential unit for CATSPA capacity building, including for competence in developing additional financing and implementing effective management. However, the EFCom's project implementation, such as SMART Program and EFcom's PAC will be showcase for complex management regarding internal practice and external support.

description.narrative: 2.2 Capacity Building Programs on Effective PA Management and Financial Planning Developed for DNP staff as well as partners; and Institutionalised within DNP and partners

comment.narrative: No such formal training or capacity building materials or curriculum exists.
Training materials and curriculum developed. Training completed for key management at pilot PA sites.
Capacity building programs on effective PA management and financial planning. Training materials and curriculum have been developed for system and site levels.

description.narrative: 2.3 Capacity building programs on effective PA management and financial planning developed and institutionalized within DNP and implemented at 5 PA demonstration sites.

comment.narrative: No such formal training or capacity building materials or curriculum exists

Training materials and curriculum developed. Training completed for key management and 5 demonstration PA sites. An Effectiveness Unit is in place to support project and is considered for long term role within DNP. UNDP Capacity scorecard performance increases 25% over baseline year.

A series of training activities have been developed on METT (with 200 participants), sustainable financing (with 80 participants) , business plans (with 70 participants), communication for conservation (with 80 participants), and SMART patrolling (with 250 participants) completed.

description.narrative: Revenue generation mechanisms and management approaches are assessed and tested at 5 PA demonstration sites leading to increased funding levels of the PA system.
3.1 New PA Integrated Management Planning Framework including tools and methods in place and implemented at the pilot units (Outputs 2.1 + 2.2 in Prodoc)

comment.narrative: Basic management plan templates exist. Most plans contain few specific requirements (actions) against clear objectives.

Each of the 5 project PA sites and 1 Eastern Forest Complex has complete, functional management plans. Site level activity plans developed and implemented in line with METT baseline result and management plan. A Clear and consistent PA management framework exists for the PA system. METT score increased by 10% at midterm & by 20% at the end.
Capacity building, including sustainable financing, leads to more effective PA management. (METT scores increased by 20% over baseline for each of 5 demonstration PAs).

Management Plans for Doi inthanon NP, Tarutao NP (combined with the Andaman Sea Management Plan), Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary (combined with Thung Yai-Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary World Heritage management plan) have been completed and are being implementing in the sites. The Eastern Forest Complex management plan has been completed and will soon be used for EFCom PAC's supporting plan and a business plan. Only at 2 project PA sites, the Mae Wong NP and Klong Lan NP are management plans yet to be completed.
The result of 2014 METT score are in this following;
HKK: 2009-63/2014-73= +10
KL:2009-59/2014-83=+24
DI: 2009-77/2014-74=-3
KC-KW: 2009-53/2014-66=+13
TRT: 2009-59/2014-69=+10

description.narrative: 3.2. Financing Mechanism Identified and Implemented at the pilot units

comment.narrative:
No feasibility or valuation studies in place. Sustainable financing mechanisms largely absent from PA system. Environmentally economic tools are not systematically applied.
Conservation Funds have been looked at in a limited way.

Sustainable financing mechanisms assessed and being pursued within at least 3 PA sites as appropriate. Community, local government and other stakeholders, partnerships leads to better management of well designed and managed funds set-up, sourcing funding from variety of sources (including PA income). Financial Scorecard score increased to 55% at the end of the project

A Conservation Trust Fund was created for Doi Inthanon National Park, with the aim to draw private sector and CSOs supports to PA management. For Doi Inthanon, a Conservation Trust Fund Committee is chaired by the Chairman of the Hotel Association in Chiang Mai Province (wherein Doi Inthanon NP is situated), with the participation from local CSOs and academics. Moreover, the first business plan for PA management has been introduced and developing at this pilot site, based on 10 selected prioritized activities from the Doi Inthanon National Park Management Plan following a participatory process. In Tarutao, the stakeholders' consultations to form the Tarutao Conservation Trust Fund, based on the diving fee and other tourism-related revenue have been conducted. For EFCOM, the financial mechanism will be PES from the Industrial Estate to support the watershed conservation and management of the complex. The valuation of water ecosystem services of EFCOM is being conducted and the engagement with the key private sector in the areas is being developed through the PAC platform. There is no financial mechanism designed for the sub-WEFCOM pilot.
The Financial Scorecard was assessed in system level. The site levels and forest complex were tested by the same scorecard as experimentation in September 2014. The 2014 system level's financial score is 29.56%, which decreased from 2012 with gained score at 33.90%. However, this decrease can be explained by a misapplication of the scorecard in the baseline exercise and in fact it was acknowledged that the there was a marked improvement since 2012

description.narrative: 3.3 Co- management Approaches Enhanced: including strengthened PAC at site-level and mechanism/ channels for public engagement in PA management established at site level (Outputs 4.1+4.2 in Prodoc)

comment.narrative: PACs are underutilized and communities and local governments are not engaged in PA management in a consistent or effective manner.
PA system. PACs in particular are utilized more effectively at pilot PA sites. METT score increased by 10% at midterm & by 20% at the end of the project

The Eastern Forest Complex's PAC was recently established by the CATSPA project in close collaboration with Regional Conservation Office No.2 (Sriracha), which has responsibility for 8 protected areas in Eastern Forest Complex. In the meantime, at the western forest complex, and in particular at HKK, Klong Lan and Mae Wong work is progressing on buffer zone management involving PAC members, in order to reduce impacts from encroachment or non-timber product collection. Moreover, CATSPA will organize 4 regions' PACs lesson learned workshops.

description.narrative: 3.4 Regional DNP Offices and PA Staff Capacities Enhanced to Coordinate Management Support and budget allocations across multiple PA in Eastern Complex for improved biodiversity conservation, management effectiveness and cost efficiencies (Output 4.3 in Prodoc)

comment.narrative: Complex plan and budget strategy allows comparison with PA level approach and optimizes management of individual PAs involved.

Promotion of Regional / complex management system leads to better management of PAs in Eastern Forest Complex (measured by METT scores of 8 demonstration PA sites within EFCOM). METT score increased by 10% at midterm & by 20% at the end of the project

Better management of Eastern Forest Complex was introduced by approaching Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) Patrol for the whole complex and the Corridor management between Khao Ang Rue Nai Wildlife Sanctuary and Khao Cha Mao National Park. EFCom's SMART Patrol is initiative approach as the complex patrolling system as well as corridor management.

description.narrative: New models of PA management support effective management of the System.
4.1 Communication Strategy and Materials developed for partnership engagement and advocacy

comment.narrative: Communication is not well integrated in PA system management
Communication is strategically planned, integrated in PA managemen and effectively support partnership engagement and advocacy

Activities conducted under CATSPA have been shared on social media and CATSPA blog (in Thai) and Facebook. Key issues advocated by CATSPA e.g. SMART Patrol (Territorial and Marine), Conservation Trust Funds, have been disseminated through social media.
A major publication Parks for LifeWhy We Love our National Parks has been prepared, stressing the values and importance of Thai protected areas in an attractive and easily accessible format for a wide general public readership.

description.narrative: 4.2 Lessons-learned Captured into Mangement Models for Replication and Policy Decision

comment.narrative: No systematic management of knowledge, policy decision is mostly not linked to study/research or lesson-learned
Various forms of lesson-learned, technical study is easily accessible, policy decision correlates with available knowledge
The knowledge management including best practices and lesson learned has been planned to collect and synthesis systematically by a contracted communication consultant.

description.narrative: 4.3. Regional DNP offices and PA staff capacities enhanced to coordinate management support and budget allocations across multiple PAs in WEFCOM for improved cost efficiencies

comment.narrative: Complex plan and budget strategy allows comparison with PA level approach and optimizes management of individual PAs involved.
Promotion of Regional / complex management system leads to better management of PAs in Western Forest Complex (measured by METT scores of two demonstration PA sites within WEFCOM)

title.narrative: FS Management of BD in Thailand's Production Landscape

description.narrative: Sustainable Management of Biodiversity in Thailand's Production Landscape

title.narrative: Mid-Term Review Sustainable Management of Biodiversity in Thailand's Production Landscape (SMBT) Project

description.narrative: Sustainable Management of Biodiversity in Thailands Production Landscape
first-order administrative division
capital of a political entity
first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: (1) 0 (2) 0 (3) Less than 2.5% (4) No mechanism established to increase staff capacity: staff capacity as measured by UNDP Capacity Scorecard is at 52% at baseline (2010)

(1) 15 with 8 certified as sustainable (2) Promotional mark operated with increased number of products endorsed (3) 5% (4) Increased training courses of Bio-academy; BEDOs staff capacity increased to 70% against the baseline at the end of project (December 2015)

description.narrative: To strengthen national and local capacity for mainstreaming biodiversity into the management of ecologically important production landscapes by transforming the supply and market chain of biodiversity based products.

1. The national governance system provides positive incentives and effective business facilitation and marketing support for biodiversity business development through BEDO and its partner network, demonstrated by:
a. No. of enterprises for community-based biodiversity business assisted
b. No and turnover from of commercial supply chain actors from project sites involved in marketing of sustainable biodiversity-based products in target markets

comment.narrative:
a. National framework for establishment of community enterprises based on local products in place via OTOP program
b. BEDO has provided targeted support approx. 35 community enterprises, but with limited focus on mainstreaming
c. Very few cases of systematic and comprehensive mainstreaming of biodiversity
d. Limited focus on export markets for biodiversity business

- at least 10 pilot products of community-based social enterprises (CbSE) supported in making high-value a)bamboo and other NTFP products, b) agricultural and horticultural products, c) marine products, d) tourism and recreation services successfully mainstreamed into the commercial markets
- at least 5 of the pilot products successfully selling into national and export markets

a. We achieved 18 products and services from 6 enterprises. Those enterprises (4 marine and 2 bamboo related) have been operated and started production under CbSE concepts; 1) use local raw materials 2) eco-friendly manufacturing 3) revenue is allocated to biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation
1. Bamboo related
1.1) Prachinburi CbSE has developed 5 bamboo charcoal products; soap, liquid soap, deodorizer, foot spa set, and face mask.
1.2) Kanjanaburi CbSE has developed particle boards from bamboo scraps. Their products have been sold as a board, made furniture and decorations. The group has also acquired OTOP certification.
2. Marine related
2.1) Chili paste CbSE in Phang Nga province has increased variety of instant chili paste with marine animal to 5 formulas (crab, 3 types of seashell, 2 types of fish).
2.2) Sea holly product CbSE in Phang Nga province has increased products variety to 5 (personal hygiene products; shampoo, soap, liquid soap, balm, conditioner).
2.3) Eco-tourism CbSE in Ranong province has fully started tourism business.
2.4) Shrimp paste CbSE in Ranong province has developed better quality products and manufacturing.
b. hi-end product
no pilot products have been sold in national or export market. The products were sold locally and in occasional events in Bangkok such as BEDO expo.
c. amount of turnover from CbSE products
1. Bamboo charcoal products CbSE CbSE Prachinburi 2,580 USD (2014-2015)
2. Bammboo scraps products CbSE in Kanjanaburi 1,060 USD (7 months)
3. Chili paste CbSE in Phang Nga 1,570 USD (6 months)
4. Sea holly products CbSE in Phang Nga 840 USD (2 months)
5. Eco-tourism CbSE in Ranong 9,830 USD (6 months)
6. Shrimp paste CbSE in Ranong 1,630 USD (2 months)

description.narrative:
2. Community-based social enterprises (CbSE) and commercial supply chains for biodiversity-based products increases family income, biodiversity conservation incentives and market share of certified sustainable production in target areas, demonstrated by
a. Percentage of certified sustainable bamboo, marine- and other biodiversity-based products produced from project sites (percentage of total product output)
b. Percentage of CbSE revenue allocated for biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation

comment.narrative:
a. No certification schemes are currently in use in target sites.
b. Interviews at target sites indicate Bt 5,000-10,000 per household/month derived from existing biodiversity-based products.
c. No systematic community funding specifically allocated for biodiversity conservation.

a) At end-project at least 30% of total product output from target sites is certified sustainable.
b) At end-project, percentage of household incomes derived from certified products averages at least 25%.
c) At end-project at least 10% of net annual CbSE revenue allocated to conservation and rehabilitation activities.

a) All 6 enterprises have achieved standard manufacturing buildings according to FDA criteria. They have submitted for Food and Drug Administration-FDA mark (safety guarantee) and then BEDO mark (BD sustainable guarantee) respectively. More than 10 products are expected to achieve FDA and BEDO mark. Only bamboo charcoal soap is certified by BEDO at this level.
b) Revenue allocated by CbSEs for biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation are 6.1% (1,066 USD) totally. Details are as shown below.
1. Bamboo charcoal products CbSE Prachinburi 100 USD
2. Bamboo scraps products CbSE in Kanjanaburi 36 USD (3.4% of revenue)
3. 2 CbSEs in Phang Nga 540 USD (4.7% of revenue)
4. 2 CbSE in Ranong 390 USD (16% of revenue)

description.narrative: 3. Increase in percentage of target landscapes and seascapes under community-based sustainable management or co-management.

comment.narrative: Less than 2.5% land- and sea-scapes managed by target communities is under sustainable management.
By end-project at least 5% of land and sea-scape managed by target communities is under sustainable management.

No increased managing area
CbSEs members and communities have conducted biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation activities such as forestation, sea-bed cleaning and local guild training etc. continuously in collaboration with local government agencies and private sectors.

description.narrative: Institutional capacity and staff competences for national support to biodiversity business established.

1. Enabling national policies, laws and regulations introduced by appropriate government departments with respect to:
a) land use rights for biodiversity business
b) Community based Social Enterprise establishment and operation
c) incentives for community-based biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative:
a. Overall policies, laws and regulations for biodiversity conservation and for mainstreaming of biodiversity business largely in place
b. several unsolved conflicts about community land use rights not settled
c. No regulation directly targeted to promote and facilitate CbSEs.
A comprehensive policy and regulatory framework for CbSEs is developed, and submitted to the relevant Government authorities.

a) 'National biodiversity policy' proposed by BEDO has been included in a 2015 - 2021 Integrated Biodiversity Master Plan of Ministry of National Resources and Environment. The master plan has been endorsed by the Cabinet and implemented nationally.
b) BEDO has proposed ACT of Biodiversity Business to Ministry of National Resources and Environment for consideration to be enforced as Laws.

description.narrative: 2. BEDO has the institutional capacities, organizational structure and resources required to act as national biodiversity business facility to facilitate development of CbSEs, as measured by the Capacity Scorecard.

comment.narrative: BEDO has been mandated in law and established, however institutional capacities for business facilitation are at the average level, as indicated in the Capacity Scorecard assessment.
The institutional capacity scores for business facilitation are raised 50% relation to baseline at end of project

According to the UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard, BEDO institutional capacity has increased by 8% from the baseline (from 42/69 to 45.5/69).
Number of BEDOs staff have increased by 83% from the beginning of the project.
Through the projects initiative and financial support, BEDO has established its National Assembly on Sustainable Conservation and Utilization of Biodiversity Resources with 12 core communities and 322 networked communities across the country.
For further improvement, BEDO in collaboration of Silpakorn University has designed Capacity and Competitiveness Development Programme for BEDO staff, aiming to increase staff capacity to follow BEDO's strategy, vision and mandates as a National focal point of biodiversity business facilitator.

description.narrative: 3. BEDO staff have the technical capacities (skills, technical qualifications and experience) needed by a biodiversity business facility, as measured by the Capacity Scorecard

comment.narrative: Baseline technical capacities assessed as low to medium, as indicated in the Capacity Scorecard.
The staff Capacity Scores are raised 50% relation to baseline at end of project

a. BEDO staff capacity score (scored by Director General of BEDO in December 2014) has raised by 6.25% from baseline.
b. BioEconomy Academy has created 12 training programmes for BEDO staff and related partners with 450 participants. At 30 June 2015, 9 programmes with 317 participants has been finished.

description.narrative: Collaboration with and capacities in Partner Networks of the Biodiversity Business Facility are strengthened

1. Through the Partner Network, BEDO has the capacity to assess market needs and demands, and to develop targeted solutions to issues such as sustainable harvesting, waste minimization and reuse, low-impact packaging, etc.

comment.narrative: Individual and ad-hoc analysis of various aspects of biodiversity business have been undertaken by partners, however no systematic and comprehensive analytical capacity.

By project mid-point, the Partner Network clearly demonstrates the capacity and willingness to partner with BEDO in identifying, analyzing and resolving sustainable production and market development issues identified in the development of CbSEs.

Through the Bio-Economy Platform established as part of the project's support, BEDO has partnered, at the national level, with the Royal Forest Department (through MOU to develop bamboo particle boards from bamboo scraps), with the national Biotechnology and the Intellectual Property Department, on product development.

description.narrative:
2. Through the Partner Network, local communities and CbSEs have increased access to extension and business development services, as measured by:
a. Number of community enterprises receiving support on sustainable harvesting and production
b. Number of community enterprises receiving support for biodiversity business development and management
c. Number of communities receiving support on biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation

comment.narrative: Limited collaboration mechanism among BEDO partners for providing extension services of biodiversity business development for CbSE
Comprehensive and systematic collaboration mechanism with BEDO partners established to provide the extension services of biodiversity business development for CbSE

a. 6 enterprises have been supported by FDA to improved manufacturing process and sites to achieves FDA mark.
b. 2 enterprises have been support by government agencies. The Tourism Authority of Thailand - TAT and Kapor district Office support CbSE in Ranong to train volunteer tour guides., Dong Bang District Administration Organization has aided Prachinburi CbSE with manufacturing building.
c. Government agencies in Ranong have supported CbSE to conduct sea-bed cleaning at nearby islands in Kapor district.

description.narrative: Community-based sustainable production and in-situ biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation is strengthened.
1. Appropriate methods for community-based monitoring of biodiversity status for data collection.

comment.narrative: Inadequate system of biodiversity status collection of data conducted by community.

Appropriate system developed for community monitoring of biodiversity status by the end of second year.
At least, 4 communities actively applied by the end of year 3.

a. Conservation and rehabilitation activities conducted by Prachinburi CbSE, Kanjanaburi CbSE and Raks Thai Foundation are summarized as follows;
1) Set up Sub-district community forest committee
2) Created maps and GPS baseline information of biodiversity resources in community forests.
3) Set up patrolling groups to monitor and control community forests
4) created biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation management and activities plans such as building a sprout plantation, distributing young plants to community member to grow in private lands to reduced usage of forest plants, constructing dams in community forests, planting training for youths, forestation and conservation camp for youth.
b. Ranong CbSE and Phang Nga CbSE with TEI and local organizations have conducted biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation as follows;
1) Marine biodiversity assessment (krill, coral reef, sea holly, and mangrove)
2) Mangrove forestation in Muang Kluang sub-district
3) Collaborated with Mangrove Development Station 18 at Bang Wan sub-district, Kuraburi district, to created biodiversity status monitoring plans
In summary, 6 CbSEs of 4 communities have monitored local biodiversity status as planned in previous year.

description.narrative: 2. Number of biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation projects planned and implemented by communities using revenues derived from CbSEs.

comment.narrative: No community-initiated conservation projects financed by CbSEs.
At end-project at least four conservation and/ or rehabilitation projects under way, financed by revenues from CbSEs.

Ranong CbSE has conducted biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation activities with their own fund for 240 USD. The amount of money was used for activities arrangement such as food and drink of workers. Wages were excluded from the budget. Community members have done it free of charge.
Kanjanburi CbSE has used budget from their biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation fund for constructing 90 small weirs in nearby forest. Those small weirs will help slow down water current during rainy season, allowing soil and plant to absorb more water and then release it back to the streams during drought period.

description.narrative: Pilot Models for Community-based Social Enterprises (CbSE) with Combined Objectives of Income generation, Sustainable Production and Biodiversity conservation are established.

1.a.CbSEs are using maximum sustainable yield as a benchmark to set production levels.
1.b.Change in marginal revenue per unit of resource use.

comment.narrative:
1. Existing community enterprises do not have capacity to assess maximum sustainable yield.
2. Marginal revenue per unit of resource use varies depending on product.

1. CbSE business plans incorporate maximum sustainable yield as a variable in setting production levels.
2. Marginal revenue per unit of resource use increases by at least 10% on average across all product lines.

1.1 No biodiversity maximum yield has been recorded at this level.
1.2 No report on marginal revenue changed at this level.

description.narrative: 2. CbSE business plans and management strategies include explicit objectives to allocate net revenues for conservation and rehabilitation.

comment.narrative: Existing community enterprises do not have specific objectives to allocate revenues for conservation or rehabilitation.
Every CbSE supported by the project has explicit objectives to allocate net revenues for conservation and rehabilitation.

Business plans for all CbSEs have been finished. Percentage of revenue allocated for biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation of CbSEs were indicated in the plans as shown below;
2.1 Eco-tourism CbSE set at 20% of income
2.2 Shrimp paste CbSE set at 20% of income
2.3 Chili Paste with marine animal CbSE set at 1 baht per a piece of products
2.4 Sea holly products CbSE set at 10% of income
2.5 Bamboo scraps CbSE set at 10% of income
2.6 Bamboo charcoal CbSE set at 10% of income
However, this system have not yet been fully functioned, still need more time to be on track.

description.narrative: Human and technological capacities in producer communities are strengthened
1. CbSEs have the necessary skills and tools to produce products which meet the requirement for certification.

comment.narrative: Community has basic skill in product development and productions.
CbSE in 4 communities are producing products which meet relevant certification standard

CbSE in Prachinburi is producing bamboo charcoal soap thai is BEDO certified. All CbSEs have applied for FDA certification. FDA is processing quality check at this level. The project has also conducted series of trainings fro members of CBSEs on key management and marketing skills.

description.narrative: 2. CbSEs have a transparent and participatory governance mechanism.

comment.narrative: Community enterprises have basic rule and regulation for governance.
Set governance mechanism which clearly includes participation, inclusiveness and gender parity.

All CbSE have substantial management structure. They have manufacturing plan, distribution plan and transparent accounting system such as dividend distribution among CbSE members, which is monitored by Department of Cooperative Auditing

description.narrative: Demand-driven design and branding of high-value products

1. Mainstreaming of high-value products from biodiversity businesses is increased through development of appropriate products designs, focused on niche-markets of lifestyle consumers in Thailand and selected export markets, as demonstrated by number of CbSE products successfully designed, branded for introduction into target markets

comment.narrative: Present community-based products are designed for local markets with little coherence with high-value consumer demand

a. At least 50% of CbSE products are designed for high-value consumer markets
b. 25% of the products from pilot communities are successfully introduced into high-value markets

No high level products at this level. The mainstreaming of high-value products from biodiversity business from pilot sites has been limited, mainly because most products are still in their development stage and have not yet been certified for high-end markets. BEDO has initiated marketing mechanisms/channels for high quality products from the communities under its regular programmes. For example, a MoU was signed with the Modern Trade Alliance, comprising more than 40 traders, which allows for bio-business products to be displayed and sold in their outlets. Other channels include the BEDO shop at the large government complex, TOPS Supermarket, Green Embassy shop, Bangkok Airways in-flight shop, vending machines at BTS stations, and on-line shops.

description.narrative: 2. Quality and value of CbSE products have been increased and meet BEDO certification standard for selected markets

comment.narrative: No certified CbSE products in the pilot sites
80% of BEDO certified products recognised by and 20% endorsed by other relevant certifications e.g. FDA, Community Product Industrial standard ()
One product is already BEDO certified (bamboo charcoal).

description.narrative: Reduction of transaction costs through transformation in the supply chains

Transformation of supply chains have been demonstrated in relation to products from the target regions, as demonstrated by
optimum of alternative supply chains provided.

comment.narrative:
No data on optimum alternative supply chains available for project sites
The wholesale and retail actors keep the majority of value added

a. At least 50% of the pilot cases have introduced optimum alternative supply chains to increase gate revenue;
b. Transaction costs are reduced in comparison to the existing transaction costs

N/A
Most products are just beginning to enter markets, with very simple supply chains. In most cases, they are sold locally or through existing networks, such as government agencies in their annual fairs/exhibitions and outlet shops, local hotels for high-end tourists, and local shops. BEDO has also set up online shops for local products.

description.narrative: Increased investment and subsidy options for Community-based Social Enterprises

1. Appropriate investment options for pilot CbSEs have been identified, as demonstrated by
a) No. of dedicated investment windows in public and private sector
b) No. of non-profit social and environmental investment funds

comment.narrative: Numerous public and private investment facilities available but not dedicated to small-scaled investment for CbSEs
80% of finance needs for pilot CbSEs are being met

N/A
There has been no systematic study to identify potential investment options/ windows to support pilot CbSEs,

description.narrative:
1.Amount of Subsidies raised for pilot CbSEs in relation to:
Not-for-Profit organisations/
Foundations

comment.narrative: There are several national and local subsidy schemes provided by government and not-for-profit organisations
10% of costs for biodiversity conservation activities are supported via Government and NGO subsidy programs

There has been an increase in government subsidy (in cash and in kind) to support biobusiness as well as conservation activities of CbSEs in pilot sites. For example, a budget allocation from Lum Sum TAO to support bamboo board production, space provided by Dongbung TAO to set up a production shop for the bamboo soap CbSE, coordinated government and non-government budgets to support ecotourism in Prachinburi and Phang-nga pilot sites, and in-kind contribution to support marketing activities of Ranong CbSE by the World Vision Foundation.
In terms of investment options and loan opportunities from the private sector, very little progress has been made. There is no clear plan to engage the private sector in the development of business plans or in providing low-interest loan schemes to CbSEs

description.narrative: 2.No. Of projects from increased CSR collaborations on CbSE and biodiversity conservation in the target areas

comment.narrative: There is limited collaboration with CSR on CbSE and biodiversity conservation and rehabilitation in the target areas
At least 4 projects from CSR collaboration in the target areas

The Kabinburi industrial estate at the Prachinburi bamboo site has been identified for discussion on PES support.
Contact has been made with soft-shell crab exporters, including hotels and resorts, in Ranong and large shrimp farms in Phang Nga to participate in PES activities.

description.narrative: Strengthened awareness about commercial potentials in biodiversity business.
Types of IEC Materials on the potential of CbSE for biodiversity business for general public

comment.narrative: There is limited awareness, campaigns, advocacy, on the potential of CbSE for biodiversity business

IEC Materials developed in the form of print, audio-visual, internet
At least 0.5% of the total communities across the country have contacted BEDO for support for possible replication
BEDO has included CbSEs story in official events (BEDO expo 2014, 2015, trade fairs in China and Japan) and IEC materials (BEDO magazine, TV scoops).

description.narrative: Integrated community-based forest and catchment management through an ecosystem service approach (CBFCM)

title.narrative: PIMS 4033 THA Community based forest mgt FSP DOA 15Feb2012

description.narrative: Integrated community-based forest and catchment management through an ecosystem service approach (CBFCM)
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration

To create an enabling policy and institutional environment for scaling-up of integrated community-based forest and catchment management (CBFCM) practices through harnessing of innovative financing mechanisms in Thailand
[no indicators]
Strengthened policy environment and systemic capacities to promote sustainable community-based forest and catchment management through PES and biocarbon financing mechanisms
1.1 Number of national policies and plans (identified) that incorporate PES and biocarbon financing mechanism in support of CBFCM.

comment.narrative:
Forestry and catchment management policies and legal instruments currently have limited inclusion of CBFCM
National/ Regional and Provincial Plans do not include provisions for CBFCM or PES / biocarbon financing.

Natural Resources and Environmental Policies and Plans adapt in implementation of CBFCM utilizing PES and biocarbon financing mechanisms as a mechanism for catchment and forest conservation and management

Key policy and legal frameworks related to PES schemes and bio-carbon were reviewed and recommendations drafted on the priority entry points, including the Environmental Quality Promotion Action Plan (2017-2021). The draft is being reviewed by the project technical advisory team and will be put for a wider public consultation in the next policy dialogue, scheduled in November 2015.
The first policy dialogue with key agencies working on PES and bio-carbon under the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) was organised and chaired by the Deputy Director General of the Pollution Control Department. There were representatives from the Department of Marine and Coastal Resource (DMCR), Department of Water Resources (DWR), Royal Forest Department (RFD), Department of National Parks, Wildlife and Plant Conservation (DNP), Office of Natural Resources and Environmental Policy and Planning (ONEP), Office of the Permanent Secretary (OPS), and Biodiversity - Based Economy Development Office (BEDO). The representatives shared the constraints and opportunities they see in piloting the Payment for Ecosystem Services in their different context. The meeting came to a resolution that, there needs to be concrete recommendations on the practical implementation of PES in Thailand in three key aspects: (1) enabling policy and legal frameworks, especially with regards to the establishment of a PES trust fund in each locality to be an operating mechanism; (2) engagement with communities to prepare their capacities and readiness; (3) policy incentives for the private sector to support PES schemes.

description.narrative: 1.2 Existence of a multi-agency/multi- sectoral mechanism for CBFCM/PES -Biocarbon dialogue, consultation with inclusive participation from all relevant government organizations, CSOa, academia, private sector and CBFCM community networks.

comment.narrative:
Seperated and disorganized data base with limited access
Lack of key agency under MONRE or government agency taking clearly responsibility, control and monitoring in this regards.
Ad-hoc Working Group established under the National Environmental Board on Economic Instrument for forest and catchment management

Ad-hoc working Group has not established under the National Environment Board on Economic Instrument for Forest and Catchment Management yet. However, an informal network of exchanges among seven agencies working on PES and bio-carbon under the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE), consisting of the 7 key agencies participating in the policy dialogue as mentioned above. In the first policy dialogue organised in June 2015, the meeting came up with two options in forming this Ad-hoc working Group: (1) the working group could be part of the newly-established Sub-committee on the Economics of Ecosystems and Biodiversity (TEEB), coordinated by the Office of Natural Resources and Environmental Policy and Planning (ONEP), and reporting to the National Biodiversity Committee and the National Environment Board; (2) the working group could be under the Bureau of Natural Resources and Environmental Strategy, under the Office of the Permanent Secretary of MONRE. The technical consultant on policy framework is now reviewing the pros and cons of the two options and will present them for consideration in the next policy dialogue.

description.narrative: 1.3 Institutional capacities strengthened at national (M&E office) and regional levels (4 pilot REO training centres) to implement PES and biocarbon financing schemed in support of CBFCM

comment.narrative: Limited knowledge and understanding in PES and Biocarbon mechanism and measures
At least 4 REOs can develop mechanisms in applying PES into pratical CBFCM and natural resource management

description.narrative: 1.4 Existence of an active national CBFCM data base (that includes relevant information such as natural resource consumptions rates/patterns, biodiversity levels, PES & biocarbon data) generated through baseline studies and participatory M & E and identification of best practice.

comment.narrative: Currently no such database exist in Thailand
Creation of a National CBFCM PES/biocarbon financing database and mechanisms for information dissemination and knowledge sharing.

The meeting with the seven agencies including DMCR, DWR, RFD, ONEP, OPS and BEDO was conducted on 9 June 2015 in order to discuss about the issues of national CBFCM database. The workshop with the same seven agencies, GIZ and USAID will be conducted on 22 July 2015. Lesson learned and best practice from project which responded by these agencies such as CATSPA of DNP, ECO-BEST of GIZ, LEAF of USAID and CBFCM will be shared and discussed. We will use the information and knowledge sharing form the workshop to create a national CBFCM PES database. The meeting and workshop of seven agencies, GIZ, and other related agencies will be conducted continuously in Q 4/2015 and Q 1/2016 in order to formulate national CBFCM database.

description.narrative: Expanded CBFCM coverage through pilot testing and up-scaling of best practice using PES and biocarbon financing schemes and mechanisms
2.1 Number and Type of PES and biocarbon financing schemes developed and applied (in place) for CBFCM in the 4 pilot sites.

comment.narrative: Currently there are no PES and biocarbon financing strategies and schemes developed and/or applied for CBFCM within the 4 REO pilot site regions.
At least 4 PES and biocarbon financing schemes (1 for each REO region pilot site) are developed and implemented during the project cycle.

There are no PES scheme implemented yet in the 4 pilot sites. Each has established the scope and the scale of PES design and the ecosystem services to be focused, confirmed the baseline information on bio-carbon, biodiversity indicators, and socio-economic data, developing community PES action plans to be matched with the private sector support. Some of the activities in the community PES action plans have been tested run, with the co-financing support from the CSR scheme from the Siam Cement Group. Engagement with key buyers are already developed and strengthened, notably in Mae Sa and Tha Chin. The economic valuation for each pilot site is underway and will be completed in October 2015. The pilot sites expect to fully operationalize the PES scheme by January 2016.

description.narrative: 2.2 Total area of cactchment forests within the 4 pilot catchment basins that benefiting from PES and biocarbon financing schemes

comment.narrative:
Current accumulative total of all forest under community management in each of the 4 catchment basin pilot sites.
Data collection on total coverage of community managed forests within each catchment basin will need to be undertaken at the start of the project.
Collectively, 15,000 hectares are identified and designated CBFCM forests within the 4 pilot catchment basins.

As the PES scheme in each of the pilot site has not been operationalized, the benefit is still at 0 hectare.
However, the project has established the clear scope of where to assess and monitor the bio-carbon benefit as well as started conducting preparation activities to prepare communities to participate in the PES scheme, including the fire break line, the check dams, and reforestation with monitoring process.

description.narrative: 2.3 Ton of CO2 sequestered and /or avoided emissions within the framework of implemented PES schemes accumulative of all 4 pilot project area catchment basin sites.

comment.narrative: Some work on assessment of forest carbon has been initiated by the RFD and DWNP for Thailands R-PIN application of the World Banks Forest Carbon Partnership Facility (FCPF) Readiness Plan, as well as by independent studies by specialists in various universities. Forest carbon stock assessment will have to be undertaken for the 4 pilot sites.
Existence of knowledge and data base of forest in term of tons of carbon dioxide equivalent sequestration

RECOFTC trained students and communities to use common methodology for carbon absorption measurement in all pilot sites. Bio-carbon measurement in the second year has been measured in early 2015, using participatory monitoring process trained by RECOFT, with engagement from communities and local governments in each area.

description.narrative: 2.4 Keystone species population maintained or enhanced at the 4 pilot sites by reducing threats

comment.narrative: Threats to forests and associated biodiversity continues at demonstration sites
Existence on the keystone speciess threats reduction measures

REOs and RECOFTC made a survey and list of indicator species in Q2/2015. Each site will conduct a workshop with communities to identify species by the end of July 2015 as well as will collect baseline data in September 2015 in Q3/2015

description.narrative: 2.5 5 % Increase in livelihood quality Index (income, health, debt and life security) of households from the baseline

comment.narrative:
Some socio-economic data can be obtained by the Community Development Department and the Department of Agricultural Extensions.
For the 4 selected pilot sites, data collection must be designed specifically for the purpose of measuring livelihood changes resulting from the project.
5 % increase in livelihood quality of life index in the projects participating communities

The average income of Mae Sa watershed, Tha Chin watershed and Lam Sebai watershed were collected in 2014. The other aspects of livelihood index (health, debt, and life security) has not been finalized yet. Average income in Mae Sa is 60,000 120,000 Baht/household/ Year and debt was 40 %. Income average of Tha Chin is between 10,000 -50,000 Baht/household/ Year; Income average of Lam Sebai is between 5,000 -10,000 Baht/household/Year. For Pha Ngan, as the scoping of ecosystem services has changed from the planned scheme in 2014, due to the lack of receptiveness and participation of the local government in the originally selected areas, the socio-economic data needs to be reworked. The data collection has started in June 2015 and is being finalised in September 2015.

description.narrative: 2.6 Capacities of local authorities and community land users in land use options that enhance PES and to ensure market-based payments from PES and biocarbon financing for improved livelihoods. Environmental Quality of key ES parameters such as water quality, soil nutrient levels, sedimentation.

comment.narrative:
Local capacities in sustainable land use options must be assessed at the beginning of project.
There has been some training provided to local authorities and community land user / community forest & watershed networks on sustainable land use practices through various government and independent projects ES and PES / biocarbon financing.

At least 4 Tambon Administrative Organisations (TAOs) are actively engaged in PES/ biocarbon scheme implementation within their respective communities in support of CBFCM
Overall land use practices in the four pilot catchment basins sufficiently improve.

6 TAOs (1 in Mae Sa, 1 in Lam Sebai, 1 in Koh Phangan and 3 in Tha Chin) in four pilot watersheds are involved in the trainings/ capacity building process organised by the projects, including the hands-on training in bio-carbon assessment and monitoring, community action plan development, and key indicator species. In Mae Sa, although the PES preparation activities are focused in the area under the responsible of 1 TAO, the other 4 TAOs which are in the same catchment have also been engaged to learn about PES and in the capacity building process. In Mae Sa and Tha Chin, the TAOs have been collaborating closely in the development of the community PES action plans, which have the potential to be integrated into the local development plans. The engagement of TAO in Lam Sebai has been improved, due to improved coordination from the project team and the field coordinator at site level. For Pha Ngan, with the change of the focused area, the collaboration with TAO has been improved.

description.narrative: 2.7 Number of national and regional level forums, meetings and documents highlighting best practice and lessons learned in using PES and biocarbon financing for CBFCM.

comment.narrative:
Currently, PES knowledge is in limited (only in acdemic society) and has no communication process intoi watershed and communities levels
PES study is limited and unclear formulation under Thailand context.

At least 4 regional best practice/ lesson learned exchange forum on PES
At least 1 National forum for PES policy strategies and collaboration (declaration of cooperation)

Project Office, Environment Policy and Institute Advisor and Environmental Economic Advisor conducted best practices / lesson learned exchange forum on PES on 22 July 2015. Speakers from Department of National Parks, Wildlife and plant Conservation (DNP) respond for CATSPA project, GIZ respond for ECO-BEST project, USAID respond for LEAF Thailand project and four REOs respond for CBFCM project in four pilot watersheds were invited to share their experience from implementation of PES schemes in local level including start up of project implementation, result, lesson learned, guideline, expansion to practices as well as suggestion for implementation. REOs can apply lesson learned from different project to implement their CBFCM project.

title.narrative: FS Promoting Energy Efficiency in Building

description.narrative: PIMS 3937 CC FP Promoting Energy Efficiency in Commercial Building

title.narrative: Basic Data / Basic Project & Finance Data
Energy Efficiency Improvements in Commercial Buildings

description.narrative: PIMS 3937 CC FP Promoting Energy Efficiency in Commercial Buildings in Thailand (PEECB)
independent political entity
Energy - power generation

comment.narrative: 1) 396 Gwh by EOP 2) 1.2% by EOP 3) 60% by EOP 4) 40% by EOP

Cumulative energy savings from the buildings sector, GWh

% of new buildings in Thailand that are classified as energy efficient buildings by EOP
Enhanced awareness of the government, building sector and banks on EE technologies and practices
% of overall commercial building stakeholders that agree to greater availability of pertinent information on EE technologies and practices through the PEECB project activities by Year 2015

comment.narrative: 80% (at least)

description.narrative: % of overall commercial building stakeholders that are satisfied with availability and quality of information available from the PEECB project by Year 2015

comment.narrative: 70% (at least)

description.narrative: Effective implementation of favorable policies that encourage EE technologies and practices for commercial building in Thailand
No. of new policy measures for commercial building EE approved and implemented by Year 2015
No. of fiscal policies approved by DEDE for implementation by Year 2013
No. of short and long term action plans for commercial building EE integrated into DEDEs national Energy Conservation Program by EOP
Improved confidence in applying EE technologies and practices in commercial buildings in Thailand

Improved local technical and managerial capacity to design, manage and maintain EE technologies and practices
% of overall no. of demo building personnel that are gainfully employing learned skills on EE building design, operation and maintenance by Year 2015

comment.narrative: 70% (at least)

description.narrative: No. of new buildings constructed that are partly or entirely based on the information regarding success of the demonstrations by EOP
Replication of demonstration projects within the commercial building sector
No. of new EE building projects designed based on, or influenced by, the results of the demonstration projects by EOP

title.narrative: 'Water for People' Partnership: Small Grants Programme

description.narrative: 'Water for People' Partnership (WPP) : Small Grants Programme (SGP)
Water for People Partnership: Small Grants Programme
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
seat of a first-order administrative division
capital of a political entity

(1) Availability of technical tools developed to mainstream Climate Change into sectoral development planning and budgeting (2) Number of budget requests from sectoral agencies incorporating climate change analysis formulated and submitted to the Bureau of Budget (3) Availability of the common framework for Climate Change analysis at the project and programme level to be integrated as criteria for the Bureau of Budgets consideration for budget appropriation (4) Availability of options for inter-agency coordination and institutional arrangements for climate finance

comment.narrative: (1) 0 (2) 0 (3) Climate Public Expenditures and Institutional Review (CPEIR) completed in 2012 but recommendations not yet developed into a common framework for budget requests and appropriation (4) No inter-agency coordination and institutional arrangement mechanism for climate finance

(1) Cost-effectiveness assessment for mitigation actions developed and tested with the Energy Conservation Fund projects to provide guideline in climate change analysis for mitigation actions under Ministry of Energy (2) 2 budget requests incorporating climate change benefit analysis formulated by two key departments under Ministry of Agriculture and submitted to the Bureau of Budget (3) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis developed and discussed among sectoral, policy and planning, and budget agencies (4) Recommendation on inter-agency coordination and institutional arrangement for climate finance in Thailand endorsed by the National Climate Change Committee

title.narrative: Third National Communication and Biennial Update Report

description.narrative: The project aims to enable Thailand to prepare its Third National Communication (TNC) under decision 17/CP7 and the first Biennial Update Report (BUR) under decision 2/CP17 fo the UNFCCC.
The project aims to enable Thailand to prepare its Third National Communication (TNC) under decision 17/CP7 and the first Biennial Update Report (BUR) under decision 2/CP17 fo the UNFCCC.

(1) Thailand's national GHG inventory system is updated and and improved (2) V&A assessment approaches and management is improved to deal with risks of climate change, climate variability and extreme weather events (3) Analysis and national capacity on mitigation options is improved (4) Information on national circumstances, constraints, needs and other relevant information is updated including public awareness on the relevance of BUR and TNC (5) The first BUR of Thailand and capacity building on NAMA, MRV, and national registry system are developed (6) BUR and TNC reports are prepared, translated, and published in Thai and English language.

comment.narrative: Second national communication (SNC) report Technology Needs Assessemnt (TNA) report in inventory, mitigation, V&A, research, and systematic observation Technical Review

title.narrative: Southern Thailand Empowerment and Participation Phase II

description.narrative: Vulnerable groups in Thailand increasingly legally empowered and protected.

STEPII is to foster a resilient society in the southern provinces to expand participatory planning and sustainable livelihood,integrate knowledge,best practices and lessons learned,in the evolving southern context,and filling identified development gaps.
Other General Services - support to civil society

1) Number of common space for peace platform in place to raise civic awareness 2) Number of pilot alternative dispute resolution (ADR) mechanism models developed 3) Number of vulnerable groups/communities benefiting from small grants projects

comment.narrative: 1) Lack of awareness and common strategic roles/position in peace process and participation of CSO, peace network and local people. 2) Zero alternative dispute resolution (ADR) mechanisms in place for effective legal services and quality legal protection 3) Zero small grant projects supported for resilience regarding participation, employment and livelihood.
1) 3 peace platforms organised for target groups 2) Alternative dispute resolution (ADR) mechanisms in place in Pattani 3) At least 5 small grants projects implemented and administered

description.narrative: A national development processes enhanced towards climate resilience and environmental sustainability
The project is to integrate Climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction mainstreamed by key line ministries into their sectorial and provincial plans, policies and budgets.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Availability of climate/disaster risk information for effective decision-making, taking into account sex disaggregated data on vulnerability and exposure 2. Level of DRR and CCA mainstreamed in development policies, plans, budgets and programs 3. Number of social innovations for DRR developed and utilised with engagement of public-private partnership

comment.narrative: 1. No evidence-based climate/disaster risk information taking into account sex disaggregated data on vulnerability and exposure in Thailand 2. No tools, methodologies, and necessary capacity to mainstream DRR/CCA in provincial and sectorial development plans, policies and budgets 3. No innovative approaches to engage public and private sectors to invest in DRR/CCA.

1. Partial information available in two pilot provinces (hazard and sex disaggregated vulnerability & exposure data collected and in progress for risk analysis) 2. Partial tool and framework for mainstreaming DRR/CCA developed 3. 5 prototypes

Advancing Anti-corruption Efforts in Thailand - A Multifaceted Approach (AAA) Project.

This project combines a number of initiatives, including mitigating corruption risks in public procurement; youth empowerment and integrity education; and social entrepreneurship and social innovations in the fight against corruption.
Anti corruption

Indicators for Output 1 1.1 Number of legal and operational guidance documents for the new Public Procurement Law drafted 1.2 Number of strategy and roadmap for building an efficient institutional structure for the new Public Procurement Law developed and adopted 1.3 Number of national public procurement training and professionalisation strategy developed
Indicators for output 2 Output 2.1 Number of Refuse To Be Corrupt cafs established Number of students anti-corruption activities funded by proceeds from Refuse To Be Corrupt caf
Output 2.2 Number of Refuse To Be Corrupt student clubs are established and active
Output 3 Number of Integrity and Anti-Corruption Education Centre of Thailand (I-ACT) established
